title: TV host interrupted by her grinning son, 4, during live broadcast about Syria

This is the moment a US news reporter was interrupted by her toddler during a breaking news broadcast about the Turkey-Syria air strikes.

NBC News correspondent Courtney Kube was reporting on the attacks on Kurdish militia in northeast Syria when four-year-old son Ryan wandered into shot.

Craving his mum's attention, the youngster is seen reaching his arms up towards her while she tries to carry on.

Courtney, who covers National Security and the Pentagon for the network, tries to gently shoo him out of shot as he flashes a cheeky grin to panicking producers.

She manages to continue but as he grabs at her she can't help but start laughing.

(Image: MSNBC)

(Image: MSNBC)

She then says: "Excuse me, my kids are here... live television," - before the screen cuts to a map of Syria and Turkey.

She later explained "breaking news in Syria didn’t line up with preschool drop-off", so she had to bring her four-year-old and his twin brother to work.

MSNBC shared the video on Twitter , captioning it, "Sometimes unexpected breaking news happens while you're reporting breaking news," with the hashtags #MSNBCMoms and #workingmoms.

(Image: MSNBC)

Courtney was reporting on the news that Turkish troops and their Syrian rebel launched the attack yesterday pounding Kurdish militia with air strikes and artillery before starting a cross-border ground operation that could transform an eight-year-old war.

The clip of the mishap has since gone viral, with NBC's Tweet gaining more than 44,000 likes and 9,000 retweets.

It comes two years after a little girl charmed the world when she crashed her dad's BBC News interview - and became a viral online hit.

(Image: MSNBC)

Robert Kelly, of the Department of Political Science at Pusan National University, gamely struggled to deliver his expertise about the South Korean president's impeachment as his two kids Marion and James burst into his office and started acting up.

In the hilarious clip, BBC News presenter James Menendez attempts to carry on with the interview as the elder child, wearing a bright yellow jumper and a grin, walks up behind their dad and starts fiddling with a toy.

(Image: BBC)

Robert, ever the consummate professional, tries to block his child from the camera - but the youngster isn't so easily discouraged.

Then the younger one, presumably sensing mischief, scoots in behind Robert in a walker and bashes into the desk, making an absolute racket.

Just to compound the disaster the children's mum Jung-a Kim does a mortified shuffle into the room and grabs both kids, yanking them out in a flurry of embarrassed activity.

A BBC spokesperson said later: "We're really grateful to Professor Kelly for his professionalism.

"This just goes to show that live broadcasting isn't always child’s play."
description: NBC News correspondent Courtney Kube was reporting on the attacks on Kurdish militia in northeast Syria when four-year-old son Ryan wandered into shot
